channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15702] Improve PerClientRandomNonceGenerator
item.description:
PerClientRandomNonceGenerator can be exposed to all the threads via the static field ConnectionManager.nonceGenerator, but PerClientRandomNonceGenerator uses Random, which should be ThreadLocalRandom or something. (See javadoc of Random.)

Moreover, ConnectionManager creates or refers the singleton instance of PerClientThreadLocalRandom with a lock or volatile, but it should be created as a static final field in PerClientThreadLocalRandom itself, and the creation will be postponed until the field is actually refereed and the class is being initialized.

The same can be said for ConnectionManager.NoNonceGenerator.

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

comments.comment: Sorry, ConnectionManager was removed in the master branch, but the issue still remains in ConnectionImplementation.
You are right, Hiroshi Ikeda. Singleton instance inside PerClientRandomNonceGenerator lazy initalized should be better.
make a simple patch

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

We can generally expect that VM implementations load classes lazily. Just create static final fields.

ThreadLocalRandom.current returns a different instance for each thread and satisfy the need to avoid conflict between threads, and moreover, under that condition, ThreadLocalRandom drops overheads of synchronization. Holding the return instance in a field not only thoroughly fails in the purpose but also introduces a thread-safety issue.
fix checkstyle and address ikeda comments.

This message was automatically generated.
Just create static final fields. That is not even "initialization-on-demand holder idiom" but googling it might help you.

Just create static final fields. That is not even "initialization-on-demand holder idiom" but googling it might help you.

Oh, yeah, just notice it. Let me fix it.
Address Ikeda comments about lazy load
The holder pattern is used when you want to create an instance later even when the nesting class is loaded. That is not the case here.
Sorry? Don't you mean singleton instance lazy load?

Is there any possibility that you use (load) the class PerClientRandomNonceGenerator without using its singleton instance? Just create a static final field. The instantiation is intrinsically delayed.

Just like this? 


Class A {

  private final static A  instance = new A();



  public A getInstance() {

      return instance;

  }



}
Or you just mean we create static final PerClientRandomNonceGenerator in ConnectionImplementation ?

I know you get what I meant, but "static" is required for getInstance and "public" just wastes for methods of a package-private class in that example.

If you want to explicitly specify that is a singleton, make a default constructor as private, but it might just have code messy unless the class is in the API.

This message was automatically generated.

I know you get what I meant, but "static" is required for getInstance and "public" just wastes for methods of a package-private class in that example.
If you want to explicitly specify that is a singleton, make a default constructor as private, but it might just have code messy unless the class is in the API.

I think i get your point.


Class A {

  final static A  instance = new A();

}

And we could call A.instance when we need one instance of A, right? And the class initialization phase in VM could keep the instance thread-safe, right?

Yes. When threads try to load the same class, the loading is exclusively done with locking the class object. That is described in the JLS.
That synchronization procedure is a little cheat and is a little different from the one Java programers use.

the loading is exclusively done with locking the class object

Sorry, that's wrong. The lock object depends on VM implementations.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se7/html/jls-12.html#jls-12.4.2
Address Ikeda comments about static field. Looks more clean now.

This message was automatically generated.
Any suggestions?

-  private static volatile NonceGenerator nonceGenerator = null;



...skip...



+  private volatile NonceGenerator nonceGenerator = null;

I didn't realize but you are right that the "volatile" is still required for a test method. That's annoying but I have no idea. Also removing "static" causes semantics change but anyone including tests seems not to expect that field has global effect.


-  static class NoNonceGenerator implements NonceGenerator {

+  final static class NoNonceGenerator implements NonceGenerator {

+    static NoNonceGenerator INSTANCE = new NoNonceGenerator();

The "final" should be appended to the field rather than the class.


+  public void setNonceGenerator(NonceGenerator nonceGenerator) {

+    this.nonceGenerator = nonceGenerator;

+  }

The "public" is not required. Even it is safe to append "@VisibleForTesting" for future developers.


 @InterfaceAudience.Private

 public class PerClientRandomNonceGenerator implements NonceGenerator {



...skip...

 

+  static final PerClientRandomNonceGenerator INSTANCE =

+    new PerClientRandomNonceGenerator();

The visibility is inconsistent. Make the field INSTANCE "public", or make the class package-private (removing "public").

HBase often names a static variable with capital letters, even if it is never regarded as a constant
